lines.text: The more I see of men, the more I admire dogs.
Rest assured, Mr. Lely, my designs are properly researched and authentic to the last thread.
No disrespect to you, Mr. Wilhelm, but your authentically tailored costume seems to have left me rather in the buff, somewhat!
No more in the buff than Japanese peasants have been for the last eight hundred years, sir.
May I draw your attention, Mr. Wilhelm, to the fact that I am not actually a Japanese peasant?
No, you are a Scotch actor who is taking the part of a Japanese prince who is posing as an itinerant minstrel.
Madam, I had rather spend an afternoon in a Turkish bath with my mother than visit the dratted dentist.
There's something inherently disappointing about success.
I do apologize, sir, that neither I nor Schwenck was here to welcome you on your arrival last night.
I do not appreciate being left upon the doorstep like a hawker!
If you'll only take the trouble to press the electric bell, Father, you'll be admitted at once. Is that not so, Pidgeon?
Indeed it is, sir.
I have no intention of placing my life in danger, sir!
How many doorstep deaths have we had thus far, Pidgeon?
None to my certain knowledge, sir.
There you are, Father. The odds would appear to be in your favour.

[on Gilbert's mother]
She is a veritable gorgon.
She is indeed, and she has chosen her own path, and in so doing, she has turned her back on yourself and myself. And for that small mercy we should both of us be eternally grateful.
Can we do that line again please, Barrington, and this time try it in English.
I'm sure we shall reap the benefits of your remonstrations in the fullness of time.
Am I to understand, sir, that you have been in communication with your mother?
No, Father, not for some considerable time, I'm glad to say.
You are a liar, sir.
No, sir. I can assure you, Papa, that the very last person with whom I wish to have any communication at all is your estranged wife, the vicious woman who bore me into this ridiculous world.
How dare you, sir? Have you no respect?
Don't misunderstand me, Father. Nobody respects her more than I do, and I can't stand the woman.
How's my wounded soldier?
He's not doing as he's told, madam.
Oh, isn't he now? Willie, are you intending to visit the dentist tomorrow? You really should try.
Oh, for God's sake, you pair of bloody harpies! Get out! I'm working!
A father should not have to seek permission to visit his own son!
The son shouldn't be expected to be clairvoyant.
Every theatrical performance is a contrivance by its very nature.
Yes, but this piece consists entirely of an artificial and implausible situation.
If you wish to write a Grand Opera about a prostitute, dying of consumption in a garret, I suggest you contact Mr Ibsen in Oslo. I am sure he will be able to furnish you with something suitably dull.
A terrible thing has just happened, Grossmith. You've become a cockney.
I don't quite know how to take praise. It makes my eye red.
I haven't laughed so much since my tights caught fire in "Harlequin Meets Itchity Witch and the Snitch".
[rehearsing a scene]

[annoyed]
"Well, a nice mess you've got us into, with your nodding head, and the deference due to a man of pedigree!"
Mr. Grossmith, you are under sentence of death, "by something lingering, either boiling oil or melted lead." Kindly bear that in mind.
[giving notes after a dress rehearsal]

Your performances were, on the whole, promising, which is more than can be said, alas, for that of the sliding doors. One of which might have thought it was in Japan, but the other was apparently stubbornly laboring under the misapprehension that it was on holiday in Yorkshire.
[laughter]
Where was the man, Mr. Seymour?
Rest assured, Mr. Barker, that tomorrow night he will be with us in Japan.
Lady Colin is irresistible. She cannot conceive why the Irish are starving when there's lots of good fish in the sea.
She most probably has a point.
[after extracting Gilbert's bad tooth]
I must say, my wife and I did find "Princess Ida" rather too long, don't you know.
[mumbles indignantly around the gauze in his mouth]
Try not to speak, old chap.

[in French]
You are going to have a definite success, sir!
Merci.
[the Armourer leaves]
What do you expect me to do, kiss the carpenters?
What are you writing, sir?
[speaks Japanese]
Mr. Grossmith, kindly oblige me by removing your hat.
Why, sir? Are you ready for me?
Would that I were, sir. And, I'll thank you not to refer to my designs as "vulgar", Mr. Lely.
Mr. Wilhelm, to my eyes, your designs are not only vulgar, but obscene!
How DARE you, sir?
Strong words, Lely - what the deuce do you mean?

Mr. Gilbert, I am a respectably married man and I love my wife dearly. Now, one of the few pleasures that she has enjoyed since the untimely demise of my beloved mother-in-law is to watch me perform upon the stage. But, I am not prepared to allow her to suffer the embarrassment of seeing me flaunted before the public like a half-dressed, performing dog!
You have my sympathies, Lely. Unfortunately, your avocation as an actor compels you, on occasion, to endure the most ignominious indignities, to which Grossmith will doubtless testify.
Without question, sir.
Well, I don't know about you, but speaking for myself, I could murder a pork chop.
Oh, there's good news from Dublin.
Mm?
The Churchills are to return to London.
Forgiven, but not forgotten.
I do hope so. Jenny says Winston is eleven, covered in freckles, and has a total disdain for authority.
What's this?
Pull it.
[Sullivan does]
It's a reservoir pen. Contains its own ink.
Good gracious me. Whatever will they think of next?

[proposing a toast]
To the Savoy Hotel.
The Savoy Hotel.
With its seventy bathrooms.
The builder was much bemused. "What's the point of having a bathroom to every bedroom? Who's going to be staying there, amphibians?"
Oh, Gilbert! You and your world of topsy-turvydom. In 1881, it was a magic coin; and before that it was a magic lozenge; and in 1877 it was an elixir.
In this instance it is a magic potion.
[in a Japanese tea house]
My goodness! It's perfectly green.
Spinach water.
Oh, Willie.
Thank you very much.
Shickerspen, preas.
I beg your pardon?
Shickerspen, preas.
Oh, she speaks English.
What did she say?
She said, "Sixpence, please."
You, do?
[referring to the chorus members belief that the Mikado song should not have been cut]
Yes, sir, we do so.
Yes, especially after all our extremely hard work and of course, Mr. Temple's.
I'm very sorry for you, but as we all know, it's an unjust world.
We all feel it would have been a great benefit to the opera.
And it's fair for it to be left to the audience to decide.
Is this the considered opinion of you all?
It is, sir.
I am not a party to this, Mr. Gilbert.
Ah, Mr. Kent, as ever the sole voice of reason!

[to Temple, who has unexpectedly come upon the meeting of Gilbert and the chorus members]
Mr. Temple, what do you make of this occurrence?
I do beg your pardon Mr. Gilbert, but I have absolutely no idea of what is taking place.
There has been a request that your song be reinstated.
Ah.
[pause]
Ah.
A most forceful request, I have to say.
[George Grossmith also comes unexpectedly upon the crowd]

[to the crowd members]
Afternoon, afternoon, please give way.
[seeing Gilbert]
Ah! Beg pardon, sir.
This is surprising, indeed, ladies and gentlemen, somewhat overwhelming.

[to Temple]
Temple, would you be prepared to sing this song at this evening's performance?
Yes, sir, I would.

[after long hesitation]
Then please be so good as to do so.
[Chorus members laugh, cheer and applaud]
Rehearsals will commence in five minutes!
Congratulations, Temple!
Laughter, tears, curtain.

Mr. Kent and Mr. Conyngham. Please ensure that you do not flinch at Mr. Grossmith's sword. You must have confidence that he is not about to chop off your heads, even if it may appear that that is your inevitable fate.
This work with Gilbert is quite simply killing me.
Working with Gilbert would kill anybody.

Lady Colin is endeavoring to persuade us to take up smoking. She's writing an article for the Saturday Review. She proposes that nicotine is a gift from the gods, and if men may benefit from its soothing qualities, why then may women not also? My poor daughter now believes that smoking is an extension of the... communion between a woman and her husband.
Will she be smoking a cigarette on her wedding day?

[laughing]
Heaven forfend!
Schwenk speaks to The Savoy every morning in code, father-in-law. Just in case the telephone operator should be eavesdropping.
One might as well open the window and shout down the street.
Barker, what are you doing? Do you propose to join in?
My dancing days are long over, Mr. Gilbert.
Over, Barker, but not forgotten.
Maude...
Yes, Mama?
Never bear a humorous baby.
I shall endeavor not to, Mama.

[to Mr. Hurley, the bassoonist]
You was late, Mr. 'Urley.
[laughter]
[Gilbert brings a samurai sword home from the Japanese exhibition]
It's a fine-looking instrument, sir. Now would that be Spanish or Italian?
Neither, Pidgeon.
Of course, sir.

[on wearing a sweaty costume during summer performances]
I fear that dear Mr. Gilbert has run out of ideas.
No!
he thrusts me into a gamut of tight-fitting pots, pans, and pails, and poaches me like a fucking haddock! Forgive my Anglo-Saxon, Mr. Butt.
How was your crossing, Sullivan?
Mercifully smooth, thank you.
As smooth as D'Oyly Carte?
[they laugh]
No, not quite, Gilbert.

[of the Japanese fan]
I'm sure I've seen this on a vase somewhere.
Now, Miss "Sixpence, Please" - what you have just witnessed is not even remotely Japanese, am I right?
[Miss "Sixpence, Please" is silent]

[to the Japanese man]
Sir - Japanese.
Japanese.
No.
No.
Thank you very much...
Excuse me, Mr. Gilbert sir, if I may?
[to the Japanese man]
Japanese.
Japanese.
Yes.
Yes.

[to Gilbert]
See, he hasn't got the faintest idea what you're talkin' about.
I have a meeting with Carte this afternoon.
At what hour?
Five o'clock.
Curious. I am to meet with him at half-past four.
Strange, I DON'T have a meeting with him at four o'clock.
It is my firm intention to prise open his purse.
It will take a far stronger man than you, Mr. Barrington, to fulfill that herculean labour.

[chuckles]
And what's your mission, Captain Grossmith?
Oh, there are certain little matters.
Dickie, have you heard the real news of the day?
Yes, the Fenian bomb. Oh, dreadful.
No - Grossmith and Barrington.

[shocked]
What?
They're off tonight.
No!
Yes.
Both of them?
Yes.
Why?
Oysters...
[gasps]
Did you swallow?
No, I chose the sole!
Off the bone?
Yes, it was rather succulent.
Wise man. Oysters can kill, you know.
Oh, unquestionably!
I had an aunt, choked on a scallop at Herne Bay.
Really?
Tragic.

[indignantly]
"Sullivan & Gilbert"? Who are they?
On the whole, the terpsichore was executed very magnifiquely, notwithstanding the topsy-turvydom befuddling Mr. Ko-Ko's entrance.
Thus. The traditional Japanese posture adopted by well-meaning, but misguided, underlings upon the departure of their august superiors.
Would that be a recognised Japanese attitude, sir?
Not as yet, Grossmith, but I have every confidence that it shall become one.

[about her kimono]
It's shapeless.
Yes, Miss Bond, it is shapeless. Japanese ladies are most shapeless.
Will you remove your corset.
I beg your pardon?
Kindly remove your corset, Mr. Lely, it will spoil the hang of the cloth.
Mr. Gilbert, I never perform without my corset!
What, never?
Shocking news from Khartoum. Something will have to be done tout-de-suite. Mrs. Temple hit the nail on the head as usual.
Oh, really? What did she say?
"The nation loses a hero, but the family loses a loved one."
Oh, how apt.
Who told you that?
Hollingshead. I played a game of cricket with him this morning before breakfast at Coram's Fields.
In this heat?
Yes, madam, but not in this attire.
Oh, good.
[Barker phones Gilbert with the returns from the previous evening, speaking in code]
U, U, plus 10 shillings and sixpence!
Can you repeat that, please?
U, U!
So that's U for udder, U for udder, plus ten shillings and sixpence!
Yes!
So you have two udders, Barker?
Uh, yes!
I always suspected as much!
[laughs]
I've made you some beef tea, Mr. Gilbert.
Take it away.
You've not had anything since yesterday afternoon, sir.
Take it away.
You can't work on an empty stomach.
I can't work at all, Mrs. Judd, if I'm being constantly pestered by interfering women with hot beef tea, cold compresses, mustard poultices, and excessive attacks of philanthropic zeal.
May I remind you, Helen, that I am not a machine.
I would not suggest for one moment that you were.
You all seem to be treating me as a barrel-organ. You have but to turn my handle, and Hey Presto! Out pops a tune.
I have other things on my mind, you know that.
Yes, I do know that, Willie, and I understand, but a little distraction will do you good.
Kitty, I don't want to be distracted.
Yes, you do.
Oh, do I? You know my mind better than I do, do you?
I know you better than you think I do, Willie.
The Hottentot in the desert doesn't play cricket. His natural habitation being the jungly-bungly tree, he is as yet hardly able to walk upright, don't you know.
Is one to presume one is to be prevented from wearing one's corset, Madame Leon?
Miss Bond, none of the ladies shall be wearing corsets during the performance.
That's simply preposterous!
Our aim is to emulate the Japanese ladies, and Japanese ladies are as thin as thread paper, inasmuch a Roman column as opposed to a Grecian urn.
You have my sympathies, Lely. But unfortunately your avocation as an actor compels you on occasion to endure the most ignominious indignities, as Grossmith will doubtless testify.
Without question, sir.
They walked downstage in the Japanese manner.
They walked downstage in the Japanese manner because they are Japanese.
Exactly, and that is precisely why they are here.
Our three little maids are not Japanese. However, they are very funny.
No funnier, however, than they would be if they all sat down on pork pies.
[Seymour, the stage manager, fills in Lely's part during a rehearsal]

[reading from the script, over-acting]
Oh, but it's too late! I'm a dead man, and I'm off for my honeymoon.
[Barrington falls about laughing]
Uncanny, is it not?
Mr. Seymour, please inform Mr. Lely that his services will no longer be required.
I should rather like to be an actor, upon the stage.
An actor?
Yes. Wouldn't it be wondrous if perfectly commonplace people gave each other a round of applause at the end of the day?
[she claps enthusiastically]
Well done, Kitty! Well done!

[to Sullivan]
I love "The Mikado." You've put everything you are into it. You light up the world. You can't help it.
[to her reflection in the theatre dressing-room mirror]

Yes, I am indeed beautiful. Sometimes I sit and wonder, in my artless Japanese way, why it is that I am so much more attractive than anybody else in the whole world. Can this be vanity? No! Nature is lovely, and rejoices in her loveliness. I am a child of Nature, and take after my mother.

[during a heat wave]
Seven dead horses in the Strand this morning. Well, one down by Trafalgar Square.
I don't know how you can sit there in your hat and coat, Barker.
I'm too hot to remove them, Mr. Carte.

[during a heat wave]
I fear we shall all have to pray for rain.
Well, if it's any consolation, every theatre in town is afflicted. Even the Gaiety, graced as it is with Madame Bernhardt's execrable Lady Macbeth.

One should be rewarded on one's merits, not on one's ability to ingratiate oneself with the management. Particularly when the management have difficulty in locating the relative whereabouts of the arse and the elbow.
I was unable to present you with the libretto until you returned from your Grand Tour of Europe.
That is neither here nor there.
No, Sullivan, indeed. I was here and you were there!
And now, sir, I am going in search of some Italian hokey-pokey, and I care not who knows it.

[In rehearsals as Koko, and pronouncing a word wrongly]
Is this a time for airy persiflidge?
*Persiflage*, Grossmith.
Is it?
It is.
Is this a time for airy persiflage? Doesn't sound right to me.
Persiflage, mirage, fromage.

[rehearsing a line]
Merely corroborative detail, intended to give artistic verisimilitude to a bald and unconvincing narrative.
No, Barrington. "An *otherwise* bald and unconvincing narrative."

[faltering]
Was that incorrect? I-I do beg your pardon.
On the contrary, it has only just occurred to me.
Ah. To an *otherwise* bald and unconvincing narrative.
Much better.
[Frederick Bovill who has the part of Pish-Tush has just sung his part in the trio in a dotted rhythm, when it is in 12 8]
Yes, but you see, I have gone to considerable trouble, Mr Bovill, to provide you with triplets. So, if you would care, to triple?
With reference to your engagement for the opera, I have a great concern about your little weakness.
Hmm... I'm a little shocked, Mr. Carte. I really do believe that my behavior this last year has been exemplary.
I'm pleased to say your tendency has improved, but I am concerned about the future.
I am acting on Mr. Gilbert's instructions. Mr. Gilbert desires the Japanese appearance, and what Mr. Gilbert desires, Mr. Gilbert must have! Fait accompli!

[during a heat wave]
I'm going out to seek a little Italian hokey-pokey, and I care not who knows it.
Thank you, Barker.
I shall not return with any for you sir... because it would melt. Au revoir.
Hello, Mr. Gilbert.
[addressing Gilbert as he is leaving the theater at the head of the members of the opera chorus]
Good Afternoon, Price.
Mr. Gilbert, might you spare us a moment of your time, please?
Of course, that's why we're here. We have to rehearse.
Please, Mr. Gilbert...

[irritated]
Yes, Price, what is it?

[hesitating]
We-uh...
Hmm?
The ladies and gentlemen of the chorus...

[patiently]
Yes?
Concerning Mr. Temple's song, sir.
Ah! The Mikado's song!
Yes, sir.
Well, what of that mercifully released aberration?
We all consider it a very fine song, sir.
Indeed, we do!
Gratifying, I'm sure, but that must be a matter of opinion, mustn't it, Price?
Well, yes, Mr. Gilbert, but we believe it a great loss.
Terrible!
